ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes it was a very good way to practice all four language skills and Professor Zhou is an excellent teacher!
Relaxed, but a good way to work on one's oral skills and learn more about Chinese culture.
It's perhaps not appropriate for anyone who is coming back from a semester in China or Taiwan, but it is still a very solid class. I would recommend this class.

I decided to take Chinese through film for the sake of maintaining my colloquial Mandarin, after spending a significant amount of time abroad in China. Generally speaking I think the course helps one achieve that goal; for someone with high proficiency it is not a course in which, however, one learns a lot of new material (grammar structures, vocabulary, etc.). This can also be a good thing, if you're looking to take a class that won't take up too much of your time. This was the first year William Zhou taught the course, and though it was a little disorganized at points, I can only imagine that it will improve.
Watch movies in Chinese, talk about them in class. Fun stuff.
Yes, a great class to take if you want to improve you listening abilities

Aside from the quizzes every day, this is a pretty chill course. You get to watch interesting films, and even though it's laid back, you still learn a lot. Zhou Laoshi is a wonderful professor- approachable, highly organized, and encouraging.
